headline: 'The Five' on flood of illegal fentanyl, defund the police movement

utterances.speaker: MAYOR JENNY DURKAN (D), SEATTLE, WASHINGTON
utterances.sentences: We've got four blocks in Seattle you just saw pictures of that are more like a block party atmosphere.

utterances.speaker: CHRIS CUOMO, HOST, CNN
utterances.sentences: How long do you think Seattle in those few blocks looks like this?

utterances.speaker: DURKAN
utterances.sentences: I don't know. We could have a summer of love.

utterances.speaker: DURKAN
utterances.sentences: Seattle saw one of the worst late night, early morning violence in recent memory. Mothers lost their children, families lost their fathers, people lost their friends. As a city, we cannot continue on this current trajectory of losing police officers like we have this year into the next years. When city leaders talk about cutting a department by 50 percent, you will lose employees. Families need security. We cannot just cut. We need a plan.

utterances.speaker: ERIC ADAMS (D-NY), MAYORAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: I'm not only running against candidates. I'm running against a movement. All across the country, the DSA socialists are mobilizing to Eric Adams. They realize that if I'm successful we are going to start the process of regaining control of our city.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEWS CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Yes, good old days, huh.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Now it's the summer of violence.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, it was a carnival of joy. Yes, she's an idiot. I mean, just putting it out there. I'm not even going to have a condition on that, she deserves the wrath of khan, and I don't even know what that means. I listen to Eric Adams and I know Geraldo has strong feelings about him. I want to love this guy, I want to believe that Eric Adams is real, right? Because he is saying all the right things. He is saying if this doesn't stop the whole country is going down.

utterances.speaker: GERALDO RIVERA, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT-AT-LARGE
utterances.sentences: Why do you doubt it?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm going to get to that because we were sold Joe the moderate. We spent -- we were told that like, you know what? Joe is basically like Trump but without the tweets. Right? And he's going to unify the country. And what happens? You know, he is just the squad in an old man suit. Right? They all jumped on their shoulders and they have a little head up there. And, I mean, and he's doing the opposite of unifying, he is splitting this country into groups that are either this or that, so that's why I guess I'm worried that once Eric Adams becomes mayor of New York he's going to have the same pressures from the same elitist activist class that Biden has, and will he roll over or won't he? That is something that I worry about. But if he doesn't, we could see something great and it could spread other cities.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: What do you think, Geraldo?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I think that Eric Adams has great ambitions beyond the mayoralty in the greatest city on earth. I believe he wants to be president, but more importantly, I take him at his word. I believe he is sincere. He is the captain of the police force. I knew him when he was the head of the 100 black men in law enforcement. I trust him. The city has gone to hell in a hand basket. He's going to rescue it. The most important thing any government can do, whatever the level of government, is keep citizens safe. Once people start freaking out about danger to them and especially their children, they act. And I think you are seeing right now a real rejection, and I believe this is why the Democrats did so poorly in the midterms, and that's why they are panicked -- or in the congressional races they are in November 2020. And I believe that this will be the pivotal issue in the midterms, and everyone is going to get on board. And that's OK with me. I don't care if they're sincere. I don't care if they really mean it, I don't care what Jenny Durkan said. I was at -- I was in the summer of love, I know what it was like. That was no summer of love in Seattle.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Jesse, actions and consequences. I mean, these cities are seeing it all across the country.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: And criminals will get away with whatever we let them get away with, kind of like my daughters. No offense, ladies, but it's true. When they saw it CHAZ out there, they thought OK, that was the signal, we can do whatever we want. And so, then they defund the police in Seattle, $46 million, a wave of retirements, shootings spike, and you know who the victims mostly were? Black Americans. So, you have a white liberal mayor teaming up with a white city council under the banner of antiracism, ends up triggering a crime wave that disproportionately affects African-Americans. Malcolm X said something about this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Geez, Jesse is quoting Malcolm X.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You never thought I'd quote Malcolm X but he actually warned against the white liberal. Because he says the while liberal will often pretend to be the friend of black Americans, but they only do that to use the black Americans against conservatives. So they'll just use them as pawns, and ends up hurting black Americans. And the city council president in Seattle, she's actually running for mayor. This is what she proposed to reduce the gun violence. Are you ready?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Programs, from hospital-based intervention strategies to trauma- healing programs. Do you guys know what that means? I have no idea what that means. And nobody else does. So, Seattle voted for these clowns. At a certain point you have to say, these are the leaders the Seattle people chose, and now Seattle is a shooting gallery. All it does is rain and coffee out there, now they shoot people.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, what's the point?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What is the point of Seattle if you can't get a cup of coffee safely.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's no "Frasier" anymore.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And listen to grunge and watch "Frasier."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But in all seriousness you actually have to hold accountable to voters. If you go into the ballot box every time and check Democrat, you get crime. And it's not even like there's an option for a Republican. Just next time people in Seattle, vote for the less crazy Democrat.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's the strategy, Katie.

utterances.speaker: KATIE PAVLICH, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: I think the choice in Seattle is Democrat or socialist.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: So those are the choices. But you know, you go back to last summer and you hear Jenny Durkan talk about the summer of love, and shortly after she said that, a 19-year-old Lorenzo Anderson was killed in CHAZ. And when the police were called, they were actually stopped at the border where the autonomous zone happened and they were unable to help him get medical aid and he died, and his family sued the city. And Carmen Best she was the first black --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: -- female police chief in Seattle, who wasn't just picked because she was a political person, she worked in the department for 30 years and had a track record of working on the street, she had all of this experience knowing how it is on the beat, so she was a great police chief had all this experience who understood what was needed. They started cutting the police budget, they started ousting her because she wanted some kind of law and order, and she did a really interesting exit interview saying, look, I feel like they set me up to fail. And they absolutely did. So, this idea now that Democrats are trying to clean up this mess that they made that was totally predictable because of some left-wing ideology that they say is based in racial justice, which actually has nothing to do with racial justice, it's actually getting minorities killed, that's one thing. The other thing now is the police is just being unavailable, because they are fewer of them, which means there are more victims on every level of crimes. Whether it's calling 911 because someone is getting mugged or there is a home invasion, and there are so many citizens who are then left with no ability to protect themselves with the government that they pay so that's why you are seeing so many people buying firearms in the cities where they are allowed to do so.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You wonder how much, if somebody could calculate how much it has cost not just to defund the police, but then when you lose these officers who had so many years of experience.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And now you lose all of that institutional knowledge, they want to hire a new police officers, but how long does it take for somebody to actually be ready?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: The mentorship, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And you have to lower the standards. You have to lower the standards for new police officers so you may not get the actual quality that you had before, and you're probably not going to be able to pay them as much because of the defunding. My question is where is antifa and BLM now?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Very quiet.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Isn't it weird, they're not in the news anymore.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: But that's why I'm proud of Jesse for bringing up the racial angle. Because who is being victimized?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Who are perpetrators? Who are the victims? It is overwhelmingly a problem in the minority community, Latino as well as black but overwhelmingly African-American. And it is a ghetto civil war. And we avert our eyes. We don't want to look at --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: We don't. We've been talking about it for a year and a half.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: No, not we. I mean we-we.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I would like to put Malcolm in the middle --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: How about lose grandpa?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Black and white.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Geraldo is proud of me, guys. Geraldo is proud of me.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: How does it look?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: That's it.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: They look better on Geraldo.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. Up next --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: He knows he's too skinny.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Fentanyl overdoses are surging in America and Democrats are being called up for blocking harsher penalties for drug dealers.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Well, I think that, I remember the crack experience, where crack as opposed to powdered cocaine was treated much more severely and it's one of the reasons the prisons filled up. I think that it's a bad strategy. Let me hasten to add that I am in favor of the border wall being completed, but it won't stop the professional smugglers. They will get that stuff in. I think you have to have an ultimate strategy, and what I would do where I end charge is, I would absolutely legalize marijuana everywhere in every corner of this country, every kind of marijuana you want. The chewies (Ph), the smokies, the, you know, any way you want to get stoned. Because I believe that if people have access, because people are going to get stoned one way or the other. If they have access to legal pot, I think that the demand of drugs like fentanyl -- which had killed Prince, it's a killer drug it's so potent, you don't know it wiped out, you know, New England, they are struck so badly. I think that you've got to understand that people are going to get high one way or the other.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: You know, Jesse, that's an argument that has been made. People have argued that if you legalize marijuana it will make drug use less prevalent. But actually, -- and that it would eliminate a lot of what the cartels do in Mexico, but actually what they've seen is that the cartels are kind of moving their drugs and they are building industrial sized meth factories now to replace their marijuana output as a result of that legalization.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: If I couldn't find pot, I don't think I would go looking for fentanyl, Geraldo. I'm not sure that's the jump, but that's another conversation. There's two reasons why the Democrats are against the sentences for fentanyl. One, lawyers. Lawyers do not like mandatory sentences for anything because they can't plea bargain for their clients. And the trial lawyer lobby owns the Democrat Party. They donated 50 million last cycle to Joe, many, many millions more to the House and the Senate Democrats. And this is such a profitable drug because it's so small, it's almost undetectable, and the profit margins are huge. And a lot of these layers represent traffickers and there's just a lot of money to be made. The mobs control it, the cartels control it, so that's why you never going to see Democrats vote for tough sentencing laws. And look who did. Jerry Nadler, New York City. Eric Swalwell, San Francisco. Cori Bush, St. Louis. Sheila Jackson Lee, Houston. Those just happened to be the major distribution hubs for fentanyl and they are against those tough sentences. Have I mentioned how much I dislike lawyers, Katie? Because this is a big reason why --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Not the first time.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I like you, Geraldo, I will make an exception. But the other reason is, the Democratic Party now doesn't want to reduce crime, they want to reduce prison populations. They believe the fact that people are incarcerated, a lot of African-Americans there, is because we have a white supremacist system, and they are the victims of white supremacy, so even if they have to, you know, reduce sentences, if that comes with an uptick in crime, they don't care.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: So, Greg, you have the opposite take. You believe in legalization that, you know, implementing more sentencing for drug crimes only exacerbates the problem?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. I think first of all, you know, the -- you know, in terms of crack of what Geraldo was talking about, the people who wanted those harsh penalties were the black communities because that's what was really killing them. But no one actually goes to buy fentanyl. No -- fentanyl isn't a drug that people go look for. Fentanyl is the cheapest ingredient that you put in other drugs because it has such a high potency given the fact that it's tiny. So, when people buy it, like, this is what kills me when the media presents an autopsy they'll say overdosed and they will mention the drugs but they don't mention what exactly -- like they will go, he had Xanax in his system. This has been done with a lot of O.D.'s. And you go like, nobody, like nobody accidentally overdoses on Xanax.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Laced.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. But it is laced with this stuff. This stuff just makes all the drugs more powerful, and it's really sloppy. So, one way to crack down on the street traffic of fentanyl is to stop cracking down on the prescription opioid users, because you are driving those peoples to the street --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- and you're punishing lawful pain in cancer patients. And a lot of these, they are not over doses. These are people that just stopped breathing because they take the fentanyl, it makes it easier for you -- you just, you get so relaxed you just stopped breathing. That's not an overdose. It's a reaction to fentanyl. So, we should view the fentanyl trade as a terrorist act --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- that kills thousands of Americans courtesy of China's massive drug trade. China knows who makes it, just like they know about the Wuhan lab. So, if they don't kill the dealer which they could very easily kill the dealer, we should think about that. We should think about how do we eliminate the dealers. We must know how to do that and it would be kind of nice. But the bottom line, any kind of war on drugs is not going to make this better, it never has. You've got to go after the source, and then you've got to legalize it and get people -- get the government and the police off people's backs.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: And Dana, the source is not just Mexican cartels but their partnership with the Chinese.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, that's the only point that I want to make here and to all of that, which is, there is an opportunity that's coming up. What China really care about one thing is money, power, and reputation. The Olympics is coming up next February in China. There's already some calls from people saying because of their human rights abuses, it should be boycotted. That's maybe a topic for another day. However, there is a meeting coming up on the end of October, it's the G20. This is where the big economies get together. And the Biden administration has been trying to do something that the Trump administration was doing as well, which is to get our allies to all be singing from the same song sheet. So when you go to that meeting and with China, I think it's in Europe somewhere, when they're at the table demanding something to be done on this issue of China laced fentanyl pills hat are coming into the United States, that is -- that is a war-type issue. And if China, if you want to get them to actually do something that would help other people, force them to close down that place. They've been doing it. They're closing down other things. They don't care about anybody losing money. They change their whole education system, their whole tech sector, and they're bringing everything back in. So, I would force them to try to do something there.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Yes. Lots of Americans dying. So. All right. Up next, Dr. Fauci desperately tries to spin the CDC's major reversal on masks.

utterances.speaker: ANTHONY FAUCI, DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
utterances.sentences: What has changed is the virus. The CDC hasn't changed and the CDC really hasn't flip-flopped at all. What's happened is that when that early recommendation was made, we were dealing predominantly with the Alpha variant.

utterances.speaker: ROCHELLE WALENSKY, DIRECTOR, CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL
utterances.sentences: I think some communities are doing that, and that may very well may be a path forward. I do want sort of comment that in some fully vaccinated then use, if they are people -- if they are unmasked and there are a few people who are transmitting there as a fully vaccinated person, it is possible to pick up disease in those settings.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I agree that they are not using -- they are not doing it appropriately. Your point yesterday about her -- this big announcement about vaccinated people having to wear masks again in hot spots where there is going to be crowds, she did that over the phone, and that's one.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Then they basically they realize, we didn't do a good enough job. Everybody is -- even the New York Times said this is really confusing and you are doing a terrible job communicating. So, don't take it from us, take it from the New York Times that's saying it, too.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, when the Times and Watters agree, that means it's true.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's a, I mean, it's like the stars are aligning. So, I think the fact also that she doesn't have to answer questions from the press is a problem. Because now that everybody is confused, like one of the questions is, so what studies are you basing this on? What do you -- and so, Guy Benson today was tweeting about the possibility that - like, Dan Crenshaw, there is a statement that said there was one study from India. And maybe we don't need to know to do all of this. So, everything is super unclear. The other thing is that, remember the TikTok Texas Democrats?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I do.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: When they went to Washington, D.C.? And remember they bring COVID. Right? So, in Washington, D.C., like, so it's 52,000 cases, right, per 100,000 people. Fifty-two cases -- it's like 52 cases per 100,000 people. Who brought it?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: The Texas Dems brough tit.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The Texas Democrats, there you go, Katie.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: The super spreaders.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You knew exactly where I was going.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. So, Katie, it looks like vaccine passports are something that could be instituted here in America. How far do you think they're going to take it?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: First I would say the majority of Americans do not believe in mandatory vaccination. They think it should be a choice and they don't want to be squeezed out of life as a result of a personal decision for whatever reason that they feel they want -- they want to get vaccinated, whether it's for health reason or if they had COVID and have natural immunity. So, politically, the backlash may be significant. I think that the left will stop at nothing to continue their control and to use this, and they are more than happy to use corporations to shame people into doing what they want to. I think they are going to run into a big political problem with the demographics of people who are not vaccinated, when it comes to minority communities in big cities. They are the ones who still need to get vaccinated. So, are they going to now try and freeze all these different kinds of people out of every regular day life of America? And also, on the passport issue, back to the communication from the CDC, the director today endorsed passports, but in the same sentence completely undermined them by saying vaccinated people and vaccinated venues can get vaccinated people sick by spreading the virus. So, you're undermine --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Are they --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: It's right here fully vaccinated venues --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: -- if they are fully vaccinated people, they're transmitting, that vaccinated person can pick up the disease in that setting.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Come on.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: So, why would you have a vaccine passport to get everybody into a vaccinated venue, if vaccinated people, according to the CDC director, are still spreading it to each other. It undermines their entire argument.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA,
utterances.sentences: I think that's baloney.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Well, she said it. Don't talk to me about it.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I know that some people will think less of me when I say what I'm about to say. I think less of people who are not vaccinated. I think that it is an arrogant, selfish, reckless act. And I have five grandchildren, all under the age of 12 who are susceptible to someone sneezing on them. I think it is absolutely so selfish that it is appalling. Sometimes government has to tell, not ask. The government has to tell right now. I want people to have to show. When I go to the bar, I want to know everybody is vaccinated or you know, if you -- or have the test.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Here's your -- here's my positive -- or my negative test. Here it is. And every week, it has to be updated.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Geraldo, whatever -- what other government instituted things, health things do you think that the government should mandate on everybody?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Measles vaccine, smallpox vaccine.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: OK, but should we be subject to seeing all of your personal records?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: But you're changing the topic.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Yes, we should be seeing all your test results.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: What if we start asking about other procedures that they've had?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: This is -- this is absolutely -- this is caveman stuff.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh, caveman. Well, Geraldo, I think 30 percent of the U.S. military, maybe even more hasn't been vaccinated.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: You know what the --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You think they're caveman?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: You know what the tragedy is --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Do you think less of the U.S. military --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: The tragedy -- the tragedy --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Answer the question, Geraldo.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: The tragedy is -- I am -- I am answering the question. The tragedy is that this has been politicized and that the right-wing thinks one way --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, you're politicizing it.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: -- and the left-wing thinks another thing. That's absolute bull. That's a bunch of crap.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You're politicizing it by saying you think less of people and calling them --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Yes, I do. I do because --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's not a good way to get people vaccinated. Let's get Greg in.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know, politicize -- the politicizing of it is bad, but also, I don't believe that your intent, Geraldo, and I'm sorry to say this, is to persuade anybody because nothing you said is persuasive. When you call people names, and I know this from my own history, it doesn't persuade anybody.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: You know, it's too bad. It's too bad.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: See, you're -- that's my point. You don't care.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: You come into my grandchildren's house and you're not vaccinated, I'm going to kick you in the -- in the ass.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, don't -- it's your house. Don't let them in. Here's the deal, OK. You are talking you are basically smearing half of the New York --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Not smear. Why --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You just said you think less of them. You call them an SOB.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Imposed ignorance is smearing?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's now -- it's now my turn.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Let him finish.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's now my turn. Half of the city -- the New York City Public Safety workers aren't vaxxed, right? So, I guess that you think that you're better than they are.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: It's not a question of better or worse.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: You just said it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You just said it. I'm just repeating your word. Let me finish. You think the 50,000 illegal aliens surrounding U.S., you think better than -- you're better than they are because they aren't vaccinated. What about this system of destructors? These are the people that don't trust the health care system, the people that understand the Tuskegee Airmen story. These are mostly people of color. They live in D.C.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: You are spreading -- you are spreading --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: This is facts.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: You are the one presenting the message of uncertainty.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, my God. No, I have to finish this because that's B.S. Mostly people of color from D.C., Maryland, and Georgia --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm going to get to that because we were sold Joe the moderate. We spent -- we were told that like, you know what? Joe is basically like Trump but without the tweets. Right? And he's going to unify the country. And what happens? You know, he is just the squad in an old man suit. Right? They all jumped on their shoulders and they have a little head up there. And, I mean, and he's doing the opposite of unifying, he is splitting this country into groups that are either this or that, so that's why I guess I'm worried that once Eric Adams becomes mayor of New York he's going to have the same pressures from the same elitist activist class that Biden has, and will he roll over or won't he? That is something that I worry about. But if he doesn't, we could see something great and it could spread other cities.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What do you think, Geraldo?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I think that Eric Adams has great ambitions beyond the mayoralty in the greatest city on earth. I believe he wants to be president, but more importantly, I take him at his word. I believe he is sincere. He is the captain of the police force. I knew him when he was the head of the 100 black men in law enforcement. I trust him. The city has gone to hell in a hand basket. He's going to rescue it. The most important thing any government can do, whatever the level of government, is keep citizens safe. Once people start freaking out about danger to them and especially their children, they act. And I think you are seeing right now a real rejection, and I believe this is why the Democrats did so poorly in the midterms, and that's why they are panicked -- or in the congressional races they are in November 2020. And I believe that this will be the pivotal issue in the midterms, and everyone is going to get on board. And that's OK with me. I don't care if they're sincere. I don't care if they really mean it, I don't care what Jenny Durkan said. I was at -- I was in the summer of love, I know what it was like. That was no summer of love in Seattle.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Jesse, actions and consequences. I mean, these cities are seeing it all across the country.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: And criminals will get away with whatever we let them get away with, kind of like my daughters. No offense, ladies, but it's true. When they saw it CHAZ out there, they thought OK, that was the signal, we can do whatever we want. And so, then they defund the police in Seattle, $46 million, a wave of retirements, shootings spike, and you know who the victims mostly were? Black Americans. So, you have a white liberal mayor teaming up with a white city council under the banner of antiracism, ends up triggering a crime wave that disproportionately affects African-Americans. Malcolm X said something about this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Geez, Jesse is quoting Malcolm X.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You never thought I'd quote Malcolm X but he actually warned against the white liberal. Because he says the while liberal will often pretend to be the friend of black Americans, but they only do that to use the black Americans against conservatives. So they'll just use them as pawns, and ends up hurting black Americans. And the city council president in Seattle, she's actually running for mayor. This is what she proposed to reduce the gun violence. Are you ready?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Programs, from hospital-based intervention strategies to trauma- healing programs. Do you guys know what that means? I have no idea what that means. And nobody else does. So, Seattle voted for these clowns. At a certain point you have to say, these are the leaders the Seattle people chose, and now Seattle is a shooting gallery. All it does is rain and coffee out there, now they shoot people.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, what's the point?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What is the point of Seattle if you can't get a cup of coffee safely.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's no "Frasier" anymore.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And listen to grunge and watch "Frasier."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But in all seriousness you actually have to hold accountable to voters. If you go into the ballot box every time and check Democrat, you get crime. And it's not even like there's an option for a Republican. Just next time people in Seattle, vote for the less crazy Democrat.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's the strategy, Katie.

utterances.speaker: KATIE PAVLICH, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: I think the choice in Seattle is Democrat or socialist.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: So those are the choices. But you know, you go back to last summer and you hear Jenny Durkan talk about the summer of love, and shortly after she said that, a 19-year-old Lorenzo Anderson was killed in CHAZ. And when the police were called, they were actually stopped at the border where the autonomous zone happened and they were unable to help him get medical aid and he died, and his family sued the city. And Carmen Best she was the first black --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: -- female police chief in Seattle, who wasn't just picked because she was a political person, she worked in the department for 30 years and had a track record of working on the street, she had all of this experience knowing how it is on the beat, so she was a great police chief had all this experience who understood what was needed. They started cutting the police budget, they started ousting her because she wanted some kind of law and order, and she did a really interesting exit interview saying, look, I feel like they set me up to fail. And they absolutely did. So, this idea now that Democrats are trying to clean up this mess that they made that was totally predictable because of some left-wing ideology that they say is based in racial justice, which actually has nothing to do with racial justice, it's actually getting minorities killed, that's one thing. The other thing now is the police is just being unavailable, because they are fewer of them, which means there are more victims on every level of crimes. Whether it's calling 911 because someone is getting mugged or there is a home invasion, and there are so many citizens who are then left with no ability to protect themselves with the government that they pay so that's why you are seeing so many people buying firearms in the cities where they are allowed to do so.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You wonder how much, if somebody could calculate how much it has cost not just to defund the police, but then when you lose these officers who had so many years of experience.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And now you lose all of that institutional knowledge, they want to hire a new police officers, but how long does it take for somebody to actually be ready?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: The mentorship, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And you have to lower the standards. You have to lower the standards for new police officers so you may not get the actual quality that you had before, and you're probably not going to be able to pay them as much because of the defunding. My question is where is antifa and BLM now?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Very quiet.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Isn't it weird, they're not in the news anymore.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: But that's why I'm proud of Jesse for bringing up the racial angle. Because who is being victimized?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Who are perpetrators? Who are the victims? It is overwhelmingly a problem in the minority community, Latino as well as black but overwhelmingly African-American. And it is a ghetto civil war. And we avert our eyes. We don't want to look at --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: We don't. We've been talking about it for a year and a half.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: No, not we. I mean we-we.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I would like to put Malcolm in the middle --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: How about lose grandpa?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Black and white.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Geraldo is proud of me, guys. Geraldo is proud of me.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: How does it look?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: That's it.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: They look better on Geraldo.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. Up next --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: He knows he's too skinny.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Fentanyl overdoses are surging in America and Democrats are being called up for blocking harsher penalties for drug dealers.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH (on camera)
utterances.utterance: Well, illegal fentanyl is flooding streets across America, but don't count on Democrats to do anything about it. They just rejected several amendments in Congress that would strengthen penalties for people who were distributing the deadly drugs. This come as CBP announces they seized over 1,000 pounds of fentanyl at the southern border last month alone, and seizures have risen 78 percent compared to last year. So, Geraldo, 93,000 people in America last year overdosed on fentanyl. It got, the crisis got worse as a result of people not being able to get legal fentanyl through their doctors because while the COVID shut downs so they went to the streets and it was laced with other drugs, which cause overdoses. And now Democrats don't seem to want to implement any harsher penalties for cartels involved in bringing it into the country.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Well, I think that, I remember the crack experience, where crack as opposed to powdered cocaine was treated much more severely and it's one of the reasons the prisons filled up. I think that it's a bad strategy. Let me hasten to add that I am in favor of the border wall being completed, but it won't stop the professional smugglers. They will get that stuff in. I think you have to have an ultimate strategy, and what I would do where I end charge is, I would absolutely legalize marijuana everywhere in every corner of this country, every kind of marijuana you want. The chewies (Ph), the smokies, the, you know, any way you want to get stoned. Because I believe that if people have access, because people are going to get stoned one way or the other. If they have access to legal pot, I think that the demand of drugs like fentanyl -- which had killed Prince, it's a killer drug it's so potent, you don't know it wiped out, you know, New England, they are struck so badly. I think that you've got to understand that people are going to get high one way or the other.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: You know, Jesse, that's an argument that has been made. People have argued that if you legalize marijuana it will make drug use less prevalent. But actually, -- and that it would eliminate a lot of what the cartels do in Mexico, but actually what they've seen is that the cartels are kind of moving their drugs and they are building industrial sized meth factories now to replace their marijuana output as a result of that legalization.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: If I couldn't find pot, I don't think I would go looking for fentanyl, Geraldo. I'm not sure that's the jump, but that's another conversation. There's two reasons why the Democrats are against the sentences for fentanyl. One, lawyers. Lawyers do not like mandatory sentences for anything because they can't plea bargain for their clients. And the trial lawyer lobby owns the Democrat Party. They donated 50 million last cycle to Joe, many, many millions more to the House and the Senate Democrats. And this is such a profitable drug because it's so small, it's almost undetectable, and the profit margins are huge. And a lot of these layers represent traffickers and there's just a lot of money to be made. The mobs control it, the cartels control it, so that's why you never going to see Democrats vote for tough sentencing laws. And look who did. Jerry Nadler, New York City. Eric Swalwell, San Francisco. Cori Bush, St. Louis. Sheila Jackson Lee, Houston. Those just happened to be the major distribution hubs for fentanyl and they are against those tough sentences. Have I mentioned how much I dislike lawyers, Katie? Because this is a big reason why --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Not the first time.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I like you, Geraldo, I will make an exception. But the other reason is, the Democratic Party now doesn't want to reduce crime, they want to reduce prison populations. They believe the fact that people are incarcerated, a lot of African-Americans there, is because we have a white supremacist system, and they are the victims of white supremacy, so even if they have to, you know, reduce sentences, if that comes with an uptick in crime, they don't care.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: So, Greg, you have the opposite take. You believe in legalization that, you know, implementing more sentencing for drug crimes only exacerbates the problem?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. I think first of all, you know, the -- you know, in terms of crack of what Geraldo was talking about, the people who wanted those harsh penalties were the black communities because that's what was really killing them. But no one actually goes to buy fentanyl. No -- fentanyl isn't a drug that people go look for. Fentanyl is the cheapest ingredient that you put in other drugs because it has such a high potency given the fact that it's tiny. So, when people buy it, like, this is what kills me when the media presents an autopsy they'll say overdosed and they will mention the drugs but they don't mention what exactly -- like they will go, he had Xanax in his system. This has been done with a lot of O.D.'s. And you go like, nobody, like nobody accidentally overdoses on Xanax.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Laced.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. But it is laced with this stuff. This stuff just makes all the drugs more powerful, and it's really sloppy. So, one way to crack down on the street traffic of fentanyl is to stop cracking down on the prescription opioid users, because you are driving those peoples to the street --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- and you're punishing lawful pain in cancer patients. And a lot of these, they are not over doses. These are people that just stopped breathing because they take the fentanyl, it makes it easier for you -- you just, you get so relaxed you just stopped breathing. That's not an overdose. It's a reaction to fentanyl. So, we should view the fentanyl trade as a terrorist act --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- that kills thousands of Americans courtesy of China's massive drug trade. China knows who makes it, just like they know about the Wuhan lab. So, if they don't kill the dealer which they could very easily kill the dealer, we should think about that. We should think about how do we eliminate the dealers. We must know how to do that and it would be kind of nice. But the bottom line, any kind of war on drugs is not going to make this better, it never has. You've got to go after the source, and then you've got to legalize it and get people -- get the government and the police off people's backs.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: And Dana, the source is not just Mexican cartels but their partnership with the Chinese.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, that's the only point that I want to make here and to all of that, which is, there is an opportunity that's coming up. What China really care about one thing is money, power, and reputation. The Olympics is coming up next February in China. There's already some calls from people saying because of their human rights abuses, it should be boycotted. That's maybe a topic for another day. However, there is a meeting coming up on the end of October, it's the G20. This is where the big economies get together. And the Biden administration has been trying to do something that the Trump administration was doing as well, which is to get our allies to all be singing from the same song sheet. So when you go to that meeting and with China, I think it's in Europe somewhere, when they're at the table demanding something to be done on this issue of China laced fentanyl pills hat are coming into the United States, that is -- that is a war-type issue. And if China, if you want to get them to actually do something that would help other people, force them to close down that place. They've been doing it. They're closing down other things. They don't care about anybody losing money. They change their whole education system, their whole tech sector, and they're bringing everything back in. So, I would force them to try to do something there.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes. Lots of Americans dying. So. All right. Up next, Dr. Fauci desperately tries to spin the CDC's major reversal on masks.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS (on camera)
utterances.utterance: After causing more confusion and making an embarrassing about-face on masks, Dr. Fauci is rushing to defend the CDC.

utterances.speaker: ANTHONY FAUCI, DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
utterances.utterance: What has changed is the virus. The CDC hasn't changed and the CDC really hasn't flip-flopped at all. What's happened is that when that early recommendation was made, we were dealing predominantly with the Alpha variant.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS (on camera)
utterances.utterance: And more COVID restrictions could be coming. The CDC could soon be pushing vaccine passports like we've seen in Europe on Americans who just want to go out and live their lives.

utterances.speaker: ROCHELLE WALENSKY, DIRECTOR, CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL
utterances.utterance: I think some communities are doing that, and that may very well may be a path forward. I do want sort of comment that in some fully vaccinated then use, if they are people -- if they are unmasked and there are a few people who are transmitting there as a fully vaccinated person, it is possible to pick up disease in those settings.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS (on camera)
utterances.utterance: She's not a great communicator, Dana. And you agree?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I agree that they are not using -- they are not doing it appropriately. Your point yesterday about her -- this big announcement about vaccinated people having to wear masks again in hot spots where there is going to be crowds, she did that over the phone, and that's one.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Then they basically they realize, we didn't do a good enough job. Everybody is -- even the New York Times said this is really confusing and you are doing a terrible job communicating. So, don't take it from us, take it from the New York Times that's saying it, too.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, when the Times and Watters agree, that means it's true.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's a, I mean, it's like the stars are aligning. So, I think the fact also that she doesn't have to answer questions from the press is a problem. Because now that everybody is confused, like one of the questions is, so what studies are you basing this on? What do you -- and so, Guy Benson today was tweeting about the possibility that - like, Dan Crenshaw, there is a statement that said there was one study from India. And maybe we don't need to know to do all of this. So, everything is super unclear. The other thing is that, remember the TikTok Texas Democrats?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I do.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: When they went to Washington, D.C.? And remember they bring COVID. Right? So, in Washington, D.C., like, so it's 52,000 cases, right, per 100,000 people. Fifty-two cases -- it's like 52 cases per 100,000 people. Who brought it?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: The Texas Dems brough tit.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The Texas Democrats, there you go, Katie.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: The super spreaders.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You knew exactly where I was going.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. So, Katie, it looks like vaccine passports are something that could be instituted here in America. How far do you think they're going to take it?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: First I would say the majority of Americans do not believe in mandatory vaccination. They think it should be a choice and they don't want to be squeezed out of life as a result of a personal decision for whatever reason that they feel they want -- they want to get vaccinated, whether it's for health reason or if they had COVID and have natural immunity. So, politically, the backlash may be significant. I think that the left will stop at nothing to continue their control and to use this, and they are more than happy to use corporations to shame people into doing what they want to. I think they are going to run into a big political problem with the demographics of people who are not vaccinated, when it comes to minority communities in big cities. They are the ones who still need to get vaccinated. So, are they going to now try and freeze all these different kinds of people out of every regular day life of America? And also, on the passport issue, back to the communication from the CDC, the director today endorsed passports, but in the same sentence completely undermined them by saying vaccinated people and vaccinated venues can get vaccinated people sick by spreading the virus. So, you're undermine --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Are they --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: It's right here fully vaccinated venues --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: -- if they are fully vaccinated people, they're transmitting, that vaccinated person can pick up the disease in that setting.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Come on.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: So, why would you have a vaccine passport to get everybody into a vaccinated venue, if vaccinated people, according to the CDC director, are still spreading it to each other. It undermines their entire argument.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA,
utterances.utterance: I think that's baloney.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Well, she said it. Don't talk to me about it.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I know that some people will think less of me when I say what I'm about to say. I think less of people who are not vaccinated. I think that it is an arrogant, selfish, reckless act. And I have five grandchildren, all under the age of 12 who are susceptible to someone sneezing on them. I think it is absolutely so selfish that it is appalling. Sometimes government has to tell, not ask. The government has to tell right now. I want people to have to show. When I go to the bar, I want to know everybody is vaccinated or you know, if you -- or have the test.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Here's your -- here's my positive -- or my negative test. Here it is. And every week, it has to be updated.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Geraldo, whatever -- what other government instituted things, health things do you think that the government should mandate on everybody?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Measles vaccine, smallpox vaccine.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: OK, but should we be subject to seeing all of your personal records?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: But you're changing the topic.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes, we should be seeing all your test results.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: What if we start asking about other procedures that they've had?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: This is -- this is absolutely -- this is caveman stuff.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, caveman. Well, Geraldo, I think 30 percent of the U.S. military, maybe even more hasn't been vaccinated.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You know what the --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You think they're caveman?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You know what the tragedy is --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you think less of the U.S. military --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: The tragedy -- the tragedy --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Answer the question, Geraldo.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: The tragedy is -- I am -- I am answering the question. The tragedy is that this has been politicized and that the right-wing thinks one way --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, you're politicizing it.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: -- and the left-wing thinks another thing. That's absolute bull. That's a bunch of crap.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You're politicizing it by saying you think less of people and calling them --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Yes, I do. I do because --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's not a good way to get people vaccinated. Let's get Greg in.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, politicize -- the politicizing of it is bad, but also, I don't believe that your intent, Geraldo, and I'm sorry to say this, is to persuade anybody because nothing you said is persuasive. When you call people names, and I know this from my own history, it doesn't persuade anybody.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You know, it's too bad. It's too bad.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: See, you're -- that's my point. You don't care.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You come into my grandchildren's house and you're not vaccinated, I'm going to kick you in the -- in the ass.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, don't -- it's your house. Don't let them in. Here's the deal, OK. You are talking you are basically smearing half of the New York --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Not smear. Why --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You just said you think less of them. You call them an SOB.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Imposed ignorance is smearing?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's now -- it's now my turn.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let him finish.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's now my turn. Half of the city -- the New York City Public Safety workers aren't vaxxed, right? So, I guess that you think that you're better than they are.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: It's not a question of better or worse.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: You just said it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You just said it. I'm just repeating your word. Let me finish. You think the 50,000 illegal aliens surrounding U.S., you think better than -- you're better than they are because they aren't vaccinated. What about this system of destructors? These are the people that don't trust the health care system, the people that understand the Tuskegee Airmen story. These are mostly people of color. They live in D.C.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You are spreading -- you are spreading --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is facts.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You are the one presenting the message of uncertainty.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God. No, I have to finish this because that's B.S. Mostly people of color from D.C., Maryland, and Georgia --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Tuskegee Airmen?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- are part of the system distresses. You can read about it in the New York Times, rather than just trying to yell at people.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I don't trust --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And then there's people called the wait and seers. These are the people that are looking at their neighbors and their friends to see what the after-effects of the vaccine are. These are people that may not have risk factors and they were waiting. These -- most of these people, a lot of these people, they're in Delaware, the home of Joe Biden. So, when you're trying to sit here and crap on Americans because it makes you feel good, you're not going to come to the buy house. We don't want to go to your house, OK. utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I'm not going to invite you. And because of that, I'm not going to invite you.

Dana has a lot of experience with liberal media bias defending a Republican president. And if you look at the percentages of positive coverage for Republican presidents versus positive coverage for Democratic presidents and just the type of questions that are asked. utterances.utterance: Chuck?

Ayman Mohyeldin is beating Chuck Todd, the political director at NBC News.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA

utterances.utterance: They -- first of all, they almost never quote a single republican or conservative ever. For example, H.R.1 would have ended voter ID. There's like -- it's like, they don't even -- they don't mention it. They use all the left terms like restrictions rather than any - -

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.utterance: Reform, yes. It's restrictions, its suppression, usually. That's the other word I was looking for. And they never cite their sources, right? So, they don't say, well, this came from the Brennan Center. Well, who funds the Brennan Center? Your favorite.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
